resources.string: In this release I\'ve added support for adding your own algorithms, a new views and extended the help view with more information. The new view is the Quick list where you can view a subset of the algorithms. There are, of course, also a heap of changes in the backend.

This application is a dictionary over the algorithms used for solving the last layer of Rubik's cube using the Friedrich method.

If you're not familiar with the notations used for describing algorithms please read the notation page carefully. It is accessed by pressing menu and choosing Notation. 

Please visit the project page for more information, http://goo.gl/n3V1D 

Enjoy!

A turn of layer is written by adding a suffix to the face's name. All moves should be applied as if you were looking at the face straight-on. Using the U face as an example here are all three cases:

U - A 90-degree clockwise turn.
U' - A 90-degree counterclockwise turn.
U2 - A 180-degree turn.
To better be able to use all of the features in this application it\'s recommended to read through the following brief documentation of each screen in the application.

On this screen you get an overview of all the cube permutations that the application has solutions for. You can scroll up and down until you find the case you\'re looking for and then click on the image to view algorithms for that permutation. \n\nTo add a permutation to the quick list, long press on a permutation and a small dialog will appear where you have the choice of adding/removing it to/from the quick list.

The quick list is a list of permutations and the chosen algorithm for each of them. The list can be sorted by the name of the permutation or by the number of times the user it, this is done in the preferences. \n\nBy clicking on an item you get to the corresponding algorithm view. If you long press on an item you will get a dialog where you can remove the item from the quick list.

In the algorithm view you see the chosen algorithm for the current permutation. 

To change the algorithm, click on the algorithm to show the selection dialog. In this dialog you can select an algorithm you like better. You can also access the dialog from the menu. 

To add an algorithm, click on the corresponding menu item. In the input mode you type the algorithm, in Singmaster notation, and press save to store it. 
If you want to edit an algorithm just long press on an algorithm.
